children: With neural stochastic differential equations, there is once again a helper form
which can be used for the multiplicative noise case (consult the layers API documentation, or
this full example using the layer

However, since there are far too many possible combinations for the API to support, in many cases you will want to performantly define neural differential equations for non-ODE systems from scratch. For these systems, it is generally best to use
with non-mutating (out-of-place) forms. For example, the following defines a neural SDE with neural networks for both the drift and diffusion terms:
are different neural networks. The same can apply to a neural delay differential equation. Its out-of-place formulation is
. Thus for example, if we want to define a neural delay differential equation which uses the history value at
in the past, we can define:
First let's build training data from the same example as the neural ODE:
For our dataset we will use DifferentialEquations.jl's
to generate data from the average of 10,000 runs of the SDE:
# Take a typical sample from the mean
Now we build a neural SDE. For simplicity we will use the
neural SDE with diagonal noise layer function:
#Component Arrays doesn't provide a name to the first ComponentVector, only subsequent ones get a name for dereferencing
Let's see what that looks like:
# Get the prediction using the correct initial condition
Now just as with the neural ODE we define a loss function that calculates the mean and variance from
runs at each time point and uses the distance from the data values:
Now we train using this loss function. We can pre-train a little bit using a smaller
and then decrease it after it has had some time to adjust towards the right mean behavior:
# First round of training with n = 10
We resume the training with a larger
. (WARNING - this step is a couple of orders of magnitude longer than the previous one).
